item.title: Capitalism I
item.description: Required Chapter 1 in Naked EconomicsCharles Wheelan, Naked Economics: Undressing the Dismal Science, 2nd ed. (New York: W. W. Norton & Company, 2010). Introduction and 1.1–1.5 in Economy, Society, and Public PolicyThe CORE Team, Economy, Society, and Public Policy, 2019, https://www.core-econ.org/espp/. Larry Elliott, “Heretics welcome! Economics needs a new Reformation” “Dismal ignorance of the “dismal science”—a response to Larry Elliot" Tom Nichols, “How We Killed Expertise (And why we need it back.

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Contents Slides Pit market Slides Download the slides from today’s lecture. Pit market

item.title: Preliminary Survey on Statistics and Software
item.description: This is an ungraded and anonymous survey for me to evaluate the distribution of your math and statistics backgrounds. You do not need to write your name on it. Please complete all problems to the best of your ability. Your responses will help me craft the course to see which material we need to focus on at greater length, especially review material. 1 Using the following sample data: \[8, 12, 9, 10, 11, 5, 15\]

item.title: Problem Set 1
item.description: Download .Rmd Answer Key For this homework, you may type up or handwrite the answers to each question. When you get to the R questions at the end, please attach a copy of your .R file (with comments!) of commands for each relevant question. For future homeworks, I will demonstrate how you can complete everything using R Markdown, but you will not be obligated to do so.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: About
item.description: This is a “hello world” example website for the blogdown package. The theme was forked from @jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme and modified by Yihui Xie.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: Appendix for Class 1
item.description: Contents The Summation Operator Definition Useful Properties of Summation Operators Advanced: Useful Properties for Regression The Summation Operator Definition Many elementary propositions in econometrics (and statistics) involve the use of the sums of numbers. Mathematicians often use the summation operator (the greek letter \(\Sigma\) –“sigma”) as a shorthand, rather than writing everything out the long way. It will be worth your time to understand the summation operator, and some of its properties, and how these can provide shortcuts to proving more advanced theorems in econometrics.

item.title: Assignments
item.description:
Preparation You will get the most out of this class if you (1) attend class, (2) complete all the readings, and (3) engageTake detailed notes, watch the videos and supplementary content, work through the examples given in the textbook, have vivid dreams about them, etc. with the readings.Also (4) ask for help from me or the TAs!
To encourage attendance and preparation, I’m borrowing and adapting Dr. Thompson’s system from his OB class that you just finished: regular self-reporting backed by the honor system.

item.title: Schedule
item.description: Here’s your roadmap for the semester! Readings include textbook chapters and occasional journal articles Assignments are due by 11:59 PM on the designated day Class materials (slides, in-class activities, etc.) will be added on the day of class Slides are “Xaringan” presentations in html that can be opened in any browserFile > Print > Save as PDF if you wish to download them Appendices contain extra explanations, math/statistical properties & proofs, and other helpful resources to keep the slides nice and de-cluttered R work Diving Right In with R Reading Slides Appendix Assignment R Preliminary Survey August 27 (Tu) Introduction to Econometrics August 29 (Th) The Quest for Causality September 3 (Tu) Meet R September 5 (Th) Data Visualization with ggplot2 September 10 (Tu) Data Wrangling in the tidyverse September 12 (Th) Random Variables and Distributions Linear Regression Reading Slides Appendix Assignment R September 17 (Tu) OLS Linear Regression September 19 (Th) Goodness of Fit, Bias, and Precision September 23 (Th) Regression Diagnostics Inferential Statistics Inference for Regression with infer February 15 (F) Midterm Exam February 18 (M) No class; Presidents’ Day Extensions to Regression Reading Slides Appendix Assignment R Omitted Variable Bias Multivariate OLS Estimators Model Specification Strategies How to Write an Empirical Paper Dummy Variables Categories and Interactions Polynomial Models Logarithmic Models Panel Data and Fixed Effects Models Difference in Difference Models Instrumental Variables Models Regression Discontinuity Models Binary Dependent Variables Models Final Reading Slides Appendix Assignment R April 23 (T) Final project due (submit online by 11:59 PM)
